mission: Create a Family Guy style comedy where dragon pilot teaches function limits and continuity. Cover epsilon-delta definition, one-sided limits, Cauchy criterion, continuity conditions, types of discontinuities, and the intermediate value theorem. Use visual metaphors: smooth flying vs teleporting, landing from different directions, altitude changes. Make limits and continuity intuitive through flight analogies.

input.original_mission: Create a Family Guy style comedy where dragon pilot teaches function limits and continuity. Cover epsilon-delta definition, one-sided limits, Cauchy criterion, continuity conditions, types of discontinuities, and the intermediate value theorem. Use visual metaphors: smooth flying vs teleporting, landing from different directions, altitude changes. Make limits and continuity intuitive through flight analogies.
input.hook: Dragon pilot teaches limits? Prepare for flight-math chaos!

output.optimized_script: Alright, Stewie, buckle up. We are learning about limits, dragon-style. Limits are like a smooth flight, not that teleporting nonsense. We approach our destination smoothly. A perfect landing is continuity; from any direction, we arrive smoothly. Epsilon-delta means getting our flight path very close to the target altitude. One-sided limits are like approaching a landing strip from the left or the right. A sudden jump indicates a discontinuity. No teleporting is allowed mid-flight. Continuity means our flight is a single, unbroken path. The Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees we can fly to any altitude between two points

One-sided limits are like approaching a landing strip from the left or the right
A sudden jump indicates a discontinuity
Continuity means our flight is a single, unbroken path
The Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees we can fly to any altitude between two points
